facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 211 of 1964 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 211 of 1964. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated February 22, 1961 of Bombay High Court in Miscellaneous Application No. 352 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February ,22, 1961 of the Bombay High Court in Miscellaneous Application No. 352 of 1959.

facts.text: Certificate of fitness granted by High Court of Maharashtra at Bombay under Art. 133(1)(c) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is in pursuant to a certificate of fitness granted by the High Court of Maharashtra at Bombay under Art. 133 1  c of the Constitution

facts.text: India Fisheries Pvt Ltd was a private limited company directed to be wound up by Bombay High Court order dated October 11, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: is directed against the judgment of the said High Court in a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution filed by the respondent. The India Fisheries  P  Ltd. hereinafter called the respondent

facts.text: Court Liquidator appointed as Official Liquidator with powers under s.179 of Companies Act 1913, exercisable under s.180 without court sanction except for sales of immovable property.

anchor.surface_text: was a private limited companypany and was directed to be wound up by an order of the Bombay High Court, dated October 11, 1950, and a Court Liquidator was appointed as the Official Liquidator thereof

facts.text: For assessment year 1948-49, respondent assessed on December 8, 1950, tax Rs. 8,737/15/-

anchor.surface_text: with all powers under s. 179 of the Indian Companies Act. 1913  VII of 1913  to be exercised by him under s. 180 without sanction or intervention of the Court save and except in case of sales of immovable property belonging to the respondent.

facts.text: On or about March 15, 1951, Income Tax Officer lodged claim for the tax with Official Liquidator.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1948-49, the respondent was assessed on December 8. 1950, the tax being assessed at Rs. 8,737/15/-. On or about March 15. 1951, the Income Tax Officer lodged a claim

facts.text: Claim adjudged and allowed as ordinary claim and certified on April 2, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: in respect of this tax with the Official Liquidator. That claim was adjudged and allowed as an ordinary claim and certified as such on April 2 1952.

facts.text: In August 1954, Official Liquidator declared dividend of 9 1/2 annas in a rupee and paid Rs. 5,188/3/- to Income Tax Department.

anchor.surface_text: in August, 1954, the Official Liquidator declared a dividend of 9 1/2 annas in a rupee and paid to the Income Tax Department a sum of Rs. 5,188/3/- against the claim made by the Income Tax Officer

facts.text: Balance of Rs. 3,549/12/- remained payable to Income Tax Department from assets of respondent.

anchor.surface_text: as an ordinary creditor. Thus a balance of Rs. 3,549/12 still remained payable to the Income Tax Department from the assets of the respondent.

facts.text: For year 1955-56, Department made demand on June 22, 1954, for Rs. 2,565/6/- as advance tax, paid by Official Liquidator.

anchor.surface_text: For the year 1955-56, the Department made a demand from the respondent on June 22, 1954, for a sum of Rs. 2,565/6/- as advance tax. This was paid by the Official Liquidator.

facts.text: Regular assessment for 1955-56: Rs. 1,126/12/- assessed as payable.

anchor.surface_text: On a regular assessment being made for the said year, only Rs. 1,1 26/12/was assessed as payable by the respondent.

facts.text: After adjusting advance payment, Rs. 1,460/1/- became refundable to respondent, inclusive of interest.

anchor.surface_text: After adjusting this sum against the advance payment of Rs. 2,565/6/-, Rs. 1,460/1/became refundable to the respondent, inclusive of interest.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer set off the refund amount against balance of Rs. 3,549/12/- for 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: Instead refunding the said balance to the respondent, the Income Tax Officer set off the said amount against the balance of Rs. 3,549/12/which was still outstanding

facts.text: Respondent filed revision petition to Commissioner of Income-tax, rejected on September 21, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: in respect of the Income-tax demand for the year 1948-49. The respondent filed a revision petition to the Commissioner of Income-tax, but the said petition was rejected by the Commissioner on September 21. 1959.

facts.text: Commissioner held action of ITO justified under s.49E.

anchor.surface_text: holding that the action of the Income Tax Officer was perfectly justified under the provision of s. 49E of the Income Tax Act.

facts.text: On November 25, 1959, respondent filed petition under Art. 226 praying for writ to set aside orders and restrain set off.

anchor.surface_text: On November 25, 1959, the respondent filed a petition under art. 226 of the Constitution and prayed for a writ, direction or order for setting aside the orders of the Income Tax Officer and the Income Tax Commissioner.

facts.text: Bombay High Court set aside orders of set off and directed ITO to deal with refund under s.48.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accordingly set aside the orders passed by the Department in so far as they set off the amount of the refund towards the tax remaining payable, and directed the Income Tax Officer to deal with and dispose of the claim

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with High Court, holds s.49E not applicable in insolvency.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore. the provision of Section 49E was number available to the Department for setting off the amount of the excess towards the balance of its claim of Rs. 8,737/15/- which the department had proved in the insolvency of the companypany

facts.text: Appeal dismissed, upholding High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, agreeing with the High Court, we hold that the Income Tax Officer was in error in applying s. 49E and setting off the refund due. The Commissioner was equally in error in affirming this order.

issues.text: Whether the provision of Section 49E of the Income Tax Act was available to the Department for setting off the refund against the balance of the tax claim proved as an unsecured debt in the winding up of the company

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore. the provision of Section 49E was number available to the Department for setting off the amount of the excess towards the balance of its claim of Rs. 8,737/15/- which the department had proved in the insolvency of the companypany and was being dealt with in the Insolvency.

issues.text: Whether s. 49E is subject to the Insolvency Rules contained in the Companies Act

anchor.surface_text: The question then arises whether s. 49E is subject to the Insolvency Rules contained in the Companies Act.

issues.text: Whether the application under Art. 226 was misconceived because the Income Tax Officer had jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Solicitor-General also urged that the application under art. 226 was misconceived because the Income Tax Officer had jurisdiction.

arguments.claim: The tax demand for 1948-49, once adjudged and certified as ordinary claim, acquired character of unsecured debt payable by Official Liquidator, governed by Companies Act, no longer 'tax remaining payable' under s.49E

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the demand of Rs. 8.737/12/- in respect of the assessment year 1948-49. being adjudged and certified, came to have all the incidents and character of an unsecured debt payable by the Official Liquidator to the Department. The High Court observed that this claim thereafter was governed by the provisions of the Company law

arguments.claim: s.49E not available for set-off against proved claim in company insolvency/winding up

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore. the provision of Section 49E was number available to the Department for setting off the amount of the excess towards the balance of its claim of Rs. 8,737/15/- which the department had proved in the insolvency of the companypany

arguments.claim: Insolvency rules in Companies Act ss.228 and 229 require all unsecured debts proved and paid pari passu; s.49E set-off would give priority

anchor.surface_text: The effect of these statutory provisions is, inter alia, that an unsecured creditor must prove his debts and all unsecured debts are to be paid pari passu. Therefore, once the claim of the Department has to be proved and is proved in the liquidation proceedings, the Department cannot by exercising the right under s. 49E

arguments.claim: Special provisions ss.228,229 prevail over general s.49E in case of conflict

anchor.surface_text: If there is an apparent companyflict between two independant provisions of law, the special provision must prevail. Section 49E is a general provision applicable to all assessees and in all circumstances ss. 228 and 229-deal with the proof of debts and their payment in liquidation.

arguments.claim: s.49E reconciled with ss.228,229 by applying only when insolvency rules do not apply

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, s. 49E can be reconciled with ss. 228 and 229 by holding that s. 49E applies when insolvency rules do number apply.

arguments.claim: Art.226 petition misconceived because Income Tax Officer had jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Solicitor-General also urged that the application under art. 226 was misconceived because the Income Tax Officer had jurisdiction.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: r. The learned Additional Solicitor-General also urged that the application under art. 226 was misconceived because the Income Tax Officer had jurisdi

arguments.court_reasoning: Misapplication of s.49E amounts to lack of jurisdiction or error apparent on face of record

arguments.claim: ITO's application of s.49E was error apparent justifying High Court intervention under Art.226

anchor.surface_text: But if we interpret s. 49E as we have done, it is a clear case of lack of jurisdiction. At any rate, there is an error apparent on the face of the orders and the High Court was quite right in exercising its jurisdiction under Art. 226.

holdings.text: The provision of Section 49E was not available to the Department for setting off the amount of the excess towards the balance of its claim which the department had proved in the insolvency of the company.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore. the provision of Section 49E was number available to the Department for setting off the amount of the excess towards the balance of its claim of Rs. 8,737/15/- which the department had proved

holdings.reasoning_summary: Once tax claim proved as ordinary unsecured debt in winding up, it is governed by Companies Act insolvency rules requiring pari passu distribution; s49E set-off would give undue priority.

holdings.text: Section 49E is subject to the Insolvency Rules contained in the Companies Act ss.228 and 229.

anchor.surface_text: The question then arises whether s. 49E is subject to the Insolvency Rules contained in the Companies Act. Section 228 of the Companies Act, 1913, provides Debts of all descriptions to be proved.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Insolvency rules mandate proof of debts and pari passu payment; s49E, being general, reconciled by applying only when insolvency rules do not; special prevails over general.

holdings.text: s. 49E can be reconciled with ss. 228 and 229 by holding that s. 49E applies when insolvency rules do not apply.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, s. 49E can be reconciled with ss. 228 and 229 by holding that s. 49E applies when insolvency rules do number apply.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction limits s49E scope to avoid conflict with special winding-up provisions ensuring equal treatment of unsecured creditors.

holdings.text: The Income Tax Officer was in error in applying s. 49E and setting off the refund due. The Commissioner was equally in error in affirming this order.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, agreeing with the High Court, we hold that the Income Tax Officer was in error in applying s. 49E and setting off the refund due. The Commissioner was equally in error

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of s49E defeated pari passu principle after proof of claim; High Court correctly set aside orders.

holdings.text: The application under Art. 226 was not misconceived; there is an error apparent on the face of the orders and the High Court was quite right in exercising its jurisdiction under Art. 226.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Solicitor-General also urged that the application under art. 226 was misconceived because the Income Tax Officer had jurisdiction. But if we interpret s. 49E

holdings.reasoning_summary: Misapplication of s49E constituted lack of jurisdiction or error apparent justifying writ intervention.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, agreeing with the High Court, we hold that the Income Tax Officer was in error in applying s. 49E and setting off the refund due. The Commissioner was equally in error in affirming this order.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; upheld High Court order holding s.49E inapplicable to set off refund against proved tax claim in company liquidation; ITO's set-off erroneous.
